title.narrative: Healing Wounds for Justice and Peace

description.narrative: This project aims to work with women survivors (and civil society organizations that want to support them) to develop and strengthen survivor support groups to become powerful forces of psychosocial support, advocacy, and change in their communities. AJAR’s goal is to promote psychosocial support and other rights of women survivors of human rights violations as a critical part of building sustainable peace, security, and a human rights culture in Myanmar. We will pursue this goal by working with these women survivors towards three key objectives. AJAR will: 1. Increase the knowledge and capacity of women survivors of human rights violations to recognize and reclaim their rights, and facilitate healing in their communities; 2. Build solidarity among women survivors and human rights defenders from different ethnic and religious backgrounds in order to lay the foundations for collective healing and advocacy for peace, human rights and justice; and 3. Strengthen women survivors to initiate and lead advocacy and awareness-raising efforts that promote healing, peace, and human rights for women survivors from all ethnic and religious groups in Myanmar.
Expenditure for Quarter 1 activities (i.e. those taking place between 1 October 2019 and 31 December 2020)
Expenditure for Quarter 2 activities (i.e. those taking place between 1 January and 31 March 2020)
Expenditure for Quarter 3 activities (i.e. those taking place between 1 April and 30 June 2020)
Funds from Donor Not Registered with IATI
Funds from the Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs for the first year of activities
Incoming Commitment from Donor

title.narrative: AJAR Healing Wounds Project Narrative Report

description.narrative: A 4-minute animated video explaining the history of International Day in Support of Victims of Torture and describing the impact of torture on survivors was produced and shared online.

Covid Impact Survey (Kachin State Capacity Building Activity)

description.narrative: A short survey of the impact of COVID-19 was conducted with members of a Kachin civil society organization. The survey primarily focused on the support that they were receiving, the challenges they were experiencing, and the impact of the pandemic at the individual, family, and community levels.

title.narrative: Soap-Making Workshop Preparation (Kachin State Capacity Building Activity)

description.narrative: AJAR Project Officer received a 2-hour, one-on-one training from a soap-making specialist on how to make natural soap. The objective of the training was to ensure that the AJAR Project Officer would be in a position to lead the subsequent Soap-Making Workshop.

title.narrative: Number of attendees
Evaluation of Survivor Work (Other State Capacity-Building Activity)

description.narrative: An independent consultant conducted interviews with survivors, partners and AJAR staff to draft a comprehensive report evaluating work with survivors from 2015-2020. The report included recommendations and was presented to AJAR in May 2020. A summary was shared with partners.

title.narrative: Number of participants in the study
Healing Wounds Introductory Workshop II (Kachin State Capacity Building Activity)

description.narrative: Like Healing Wounds Introductory Workshop I, this was a 3-day workshop designed for approximately 5-10 participants and intended to introduce participants to the Healing Wounds project and its objectives. The workshop included general discussion of self-care and deep listening as well as some practice with deep listening. One of the goals of the workshop was to begin to identify individuals who would be willing and able to commit to participating in the Healing Wounds project. Female survivors from the Sama region in Myanmar who did not previously participate in the Healing Wounds Introductory Workshop I participated in this workshop.

title.narrative: Public Seminar on International Day in Support of Victims of Torture (Awareness-Building Event)

description.narrative: On International Day in Support of Victims of Torture, this 2-hour public seminar to build awareness and understanding was held online (due to COVID-19 constraints). Members of local civil society organizations spoke about the ongoing use of torture in Myanmar and made recommendations for stopping the practice and addressing its impact on survivors.

Earth Brick Making Workshop (Kachin State Capacity Building Activity)

description.narrative: This 3-day workshop with female survivors from the Sama region in Myanmar was the first in a series of workshops created in response to requests for increased livelihood training. The objective of the workshop was to introduce the participants to the process of earth brick making and provide them an opportunity to practice building bricks themselves. In addition, the workshop was intended to help the participants begin to think about how they can incorporate earth brick making (and building) into their own lives, envision building their own houses using natural materials in the future. On the first day, the participants were introduced to the concept and use of earth bricks as a sustainable building material and were taught the process for making earth bricks. The remaining two days were used to make earth bricks. (Over 450 bricks were made, significantly exceeding the 400 brick target.)

title.narrative: Number of attendees (excluding AJAR staff)
Earth Brick Building Workshop (Kachin State Capacity Building Activity)

description.narrative: This 3-day workshop with female survivors from the Sama region in Myanmar was the second in a series of workshops created in response to requests for increased livelihood training. The objective of the workshop was to teach participants how to build with earth bricks by constructing a pee-toilet out of earth bricks previously made by the participants. In addition, the workshop was intended to help the participants further think about how they can incorporate earth brick building into their own lives.

title.narrative: Number of attendees (excluding AJAR staff)

Scrapbooking Workshop (Other State Capacity-Building Activity)

description.narrative: This 4-day workshop held in Central Burma brought together female survivors and civil society leaders from throughout Myanmar and two survivors from Papua, Indonesia to learn the technique of scrapbooking to advance psychosocial healing. During the session, the participants shared their own stories and learned about each other's experiences.

title.narrative: Basic Methodologies Workshop (Kachin State Capacity Building Activity)

description.narrative: This was a 2-day workshop with female survivors from the Sama region. The objective of this workshop was to introduce the participants to basic methodologies for psychosocial healing (such as the Circle Tool) created by AJAR. In addition, the workshop was intended to help participants begin to think about how their stories are important to democracy and society in Burma and how they can play a crucial role in democracy and society in Burma.

Comparative Learning Workshop (Other State Psychosocial, Documentation, or Networking Activity)

description.narrative: This was a 4-hour seesion where representatives from civil society organizations in Myanmar gathered to hear from a speaker from South Africa. The speaker discussed the end of apartheid in South Africa and South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission, sharing lessons learned from South Africa's journey to democracy. The session also provided an opportunity for the civil society members to dialogue and interact with each other.

title.narrative: Emergence of women survivor facilitators
Number of women survivors confidently facilitating peace, healing, and justice (identified through surveys and evaluations of most significant change)
Increased public understanding of women survivors' rights and justice

Number of members of the public who gain awareness of the rights of women survivors and their struggle for community-based transitional justice (identified through surveys and evaluations of most significant change)
Increased public understanding through multi-media product

Number of members of the public who gain new knowledge on the rights of women survivors by watching, listening to, or reading a multimedia product (identified through surveys and evaluations of most significant change)
Increased public understanding of female survivors

Number of members of the public (including civil society activists and policymakers) who obtain information about the rights of women survivors by attending public awareness events (identified through surveys and evaluations of most significant change)
Survivors build solidarity with others outside Myanmar

Number of women survivors connecting with, gaining insight from, and building solidarity with women survivors from other countries (identified through surveys and evaluations of most significant change)
Survivors gain new knowledge, insight, and methodologies
Number of women survivors reporting new knowledge, insight, and methodologies (identified through surveys and evaluations of most significant change)
Increase of women survivors’ skills and knowledge of psychosocial support and human rights
Number of women survivors with their skills and knowledge integrated (identified through surveys and evaluations of most significant change)
Increase in community support, learning, and documentation

Number of women survivors, their family members, and/or community members receiving psychosocial support, learning, and/or having their stories documented (identified through surveys and evaluations of most significant change)
Survivors build solidarity with others in Myanmar
Number of women survivors connecting with, gaining insight from, and building solidarity with other women survivors in Myanmar (identified through surveys and evaluations of most significant change)
Survivors increase confidence and experience speaking out
Number of women survivors who report gaining confidence and experience in speaking out (identified through surveys and evaluations of most significant change)
An emerging Kachin civil society organization's work is supported
Most significant change

description.narrative: Stories of most significant change gathered through surveys, formal evaluations, informal evaluations, and discussions)

target.value: Members attest to and demonstrate basic computer, writing, and administration skills that are improving their work and sustaining the organization's objective

actual.value: Members attest to and demonstrate basic computer, writing, and administration skills that are improving their work and sustaining the organization's objective
